title: 112_hr3829
content: The "Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012" or the "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" requires a criminal background check under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" mandates a criminal background check for child care staff, family child care providers, and adults living in the home of a family child care provider. The check includes searches of national and state criminal databases, as well as abuse and neglect registries. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" requires criminal background checks for child care providers, including searches of state abuse registries and FBI fingerprint checks. Providers are ineligible for funds if they have adult felony convictions related to child abuse, spousal abuse, or crimes against children. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" mandates criminal background checks for child care providers, including state abuse registry searches and FBI fingerprint checks. Providers are disqualified from receiving funds if they have adult felony convictions for child abuse, spousal abuse, crimes against children, violent crimes, or drug offenses within the last 5 years. Child care providers must submit requests for State and national criminal background checks to the designated State agency. This applies to staff members, family providers, and adults residing in the provider's home. Checks must be done before a specified date and every 5 years thereafter. Child care providers must request State and national criminal background checks for staff members, family providers, and adults living in their home before a specified date and every 5 years thereafter. Child care providers must request State and national criminal background checks for staff members, family providers, and adults living in their home before a specified date and every 5 years thereafter. Limitation on requests: Only one request is needed for each individual residing in the provider's private residence every 5 years. Results must be provided within 10 business days of the request being made to the appropriate State agency. Child care providers must request State and national criminal background checks for staff members, family providers, and adults living in their home. The State agency must provide the results within 10 business days. States must ensure accuracy by obtaining dispositions of arrests and correcting any inaccurate information. Upon request, a copy of the background check must be provided to the child care provider or individual subject to the check. Child care providers or individuals can appeal the results of a criminal background check within 30 days to the designated State agency. The State must make a final ruling within 30 days of the appeal. Child care providers can appeal the results of a criminal background check to the State agency within 30 days. The State must make a final ruling on eligibility, provide specific findings, make changes to the individual's record if needed, and report back. States can collect a fee for background checks to cover costs. The Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012 allows child care providers to appeal criminal background check results within 30 days. States can collect a fee not exceeding $36 per background check to cover costs. States must implement the requirements within 3 years, with a possible 2-year extension for good faith efforts. The term "adult" refers to individuals aged 18 and above. The Secretary can grant a 2-year extension to States making a good faith effort to meet the requirements of the Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012. Definitions include 'adult' as individuals aged 18 and above, 'child care provider' as licensed providers, and 'child care staff member' as individuals providing child care services for compensation. The term 'child care staff member' refers to an individual who provides child care services for compensation on a regular basis, excluding those related to the children in their care. A 'family child care provider' is an individual who provides child care services for fewer than 24 hours per day in a private residence, not related to all the children in their care, and is licensed, regulated, or receives funds under State law. The term 'child care staff member' refers to an individual who provides child care services for compensation on a regular basis, excluding those related to the children in their care. A 'family child care provider' is an individual who provides child care services in a private residence, not related to all the children in their care, and is licensed, regulated, or receives funds under State law. Authorization of appropriations is provided for conducting criminal background checks for child care providers.
